ANNALISA WEIGEL: Our next
module is called People-- The Heart of Lean. And I'm going to start
out with you by giving you

the two primary messages
that I want you to take away from this module. Those of you who've either
taken classes with me

or written papers with me or
made presentations with me know I'm a big fan of this-- putting all the
messages up front--

because I want you to be able
to hear how they are confirmed by some of the data
I'm going to show you and some of the concepts
we're talking about.

So the first is
that lean can only work if the people who
are doing the work really want it to succeed.

And we saw that echoed at
the New Balance plant tour. We've heard that talked
about in many modules

during the course of
this three-day class. The second one is that each
one of you in this room

are, very shortly, going
to be in a position to influence and to motivate
people and have the power

to actually make a difference. And we want you to pay
attention to it for that reason, because it's going
to be very important.

So there are two
distinctive features of a lot of these lean systems.

And a lot of time we spend
focusing here on the production aspects of just-in-time.

But there's also a
second system going on that these authors have called
the respect-for-human system.

And they define it
as a place where workers are allowed to display,
in full, their capabilities

through active participation
and running and improving their own workshops. So we saw this at the
New Balance factory tour.

And it was embodied
by that eighth waste that they put up on the board. We had shown you seven in
class, and they had an eighth.

The Eighth waste was
employee creativity. That's something that they
did not want to waste. And it speaks very
powerfully to how much they

have taken to heart
and implemented the respect-for-human
system in their plant.

As engineers, we
spend a lot of time learning about, practicing
doing problem sets about,

what we think of
as the hard stuff-- all of the technical knowledge,
the engineering science we're trying to learn.

But as you have heard from
a bunch of practitioners through the course
of this class,

the hard stuff is
not the hard stuff. What's really hard is what
they call the soft stuff--

things that involve
people, things that involve changing culture,
changing work practices.

So at the end of
this module, we want you to be able to
explain why people really are the key to improving
productivity in organizations,

describe how you can be an
effective member of a team, and be able to
compare and contrast

a little bit about
leadership and management.

We're going to start with a
brief active-learning exercise. And the question we'd
like you to think about is, what are the most important
things that contribute

to your job satisfaction? So is that being a
student in a class? Or maybe you want to
think about participating

in an internship at a company. Think about the
things that really matter to you that made you feel
like your job was satisfying.

I'm going to ask
for a brainstorm, and I'm going to ask Hugh to
come and be our note-taker.

Thank you, Hugh. And I want to get a good amount
of these up on the board.

And then what I'd like to do
is, you'll take your sticky dots that I handed out earlier.

And I'd like you to select
your three top reasons that are on the board for
job satisfaction.

Then we're going
to be able to look to see where the
preponderance is in the room. All right. So let's start the brainstorm
with things that contribute
to your job satisfaction. Anybody? Tim. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

ANNALISA WEIGEL: Go
ahead, Tim, first. Then [INAUDIBLE]. AUDIENCE: --recognition
of achievement. ANNALISA WEIGEL:
Recognition of achievement.

Mentor. So you would like to mentor? AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] ANNALISA WEIGEL: OK. AUDIENCE: You learn from
them, they learn from you.

ANNALISA WEIGEL: OK.  Let's stop our
brainstorming there

unless somebody feels that there
are one, two, or three choices not already up here.

So take your dots. And before everybody makes a

Have those chosen first. And then go up to the board and

next to number two

and a dot next to number three. The only rules are, you cannot

so that we can get

and placing your dots.

Remember, one dot to one item. Yes. You can only use three dots,
even though your strips

have four or more. It's a mismatch between

and the nature of the exercise. So you get one left over
that you can-- yeah, you can put on your nose or
your forehead or something

like that.  OK. So let's take a look at how your
preferences fell out as a class

while I'm blinded
by the projector. So your top choice, although
it was a little bit of a tie-- we had intellectual
challenge as number one.

Personal contribution and making
a difference is a close second. And even a close third is having
good colleagues to work with.

Notice a couple of outliers. So pay is coming up
here as number eight--

as eight votes-- number four. So that's still important,
but it didn't quite make our top three.

Interesting to note. I'd like to compare your
answers to some data we

have from a survey that was
actually done by Boeing. They do this every year and
ask about the components

of a person's job that
are important to their job satisfaction. And we see a lot
of similar results.

What I'd like to start pointing
out is that things in this side have a low correlation
with job satisfaction.

Things on this side of the
chart have a higher correlation with job satisfaction.

So notice that pay
is down here, lowest among the respondents of the
survey who filled this out.

And while it's not quite as
low as our ranking of pay here, I think some of
these other issues

that we found are also
ahead of pay in ours as well as in theirs. So some of the top ones--

they're involved in decisions. You might think about that
as making a difference.

They're encouraged to come
up with new and better ways, make good use of the skills. They get recognition for
doing a job well done.

The conditions allow
me to be productive. And they have opportunities
to improve their skills.

These are all the things that
came up as the key drivers to job satisfactions,
which is contrary to what a lot of people
think, which is, well,

if I just get paid a
lot, that's a great job, and I'm going to
be really happy.

So what really makes
a worker happy, then? We have two different
schools of thought

that have emerged over time. So our first one was
proposed back in the 1920s.

A happy worker is a
productive worker. That was a school of thought. So if you believe that
a happy worker led

to a productive worker,
what would your strategy be, as a manager?

Make people happy, right? So arose the culture of a lot
of human-resource departments and the focus on trying to
keep workers happy in the hopes

that that would make
them productive. Now, in this day and
age, around 2000,

we really have a somewhat
similar but reflexive take on that, that a productive
worker is really

a happy worker. And this is where
lean comes from. Work on productivity,
work on making people

able to contribute
and make a difference, and then the result
is happiness. But either way that
you look at it,

this is really a
very virtuous circle. There's some link between
happiness and productivity. And regardless of
which way the causality

goes, if we are working
towards both of those, we're having a good team.

So I want to take a
couple charts to show you some research and
quantitative examples that

link employee productivity
to employee happiness.

And I'm going to use a
case of Southwest Airlines. And there was a
wonderful case study that was done on this
by Professor Jody Hoffer

Gittell, who actually did
her PhD work here at MIT. And she's now at Brandeis
University on the faculty

there. Just to give you a basic
overview of Southwest Airlines, they're known in the industry
for having made a profit

every year since it
started operation, even in some of the down times. You can see here, the industry
average profit is in the red.

This axis, which doesn't
show up well on the screen here, in gray, is
the balance between

unprofitable and profitable. Southwest is in the blue. Lots of people have
looked towards Southwest

as a great example. Certainly, everyone in
the airline industry looks at Southwest
and what they're doing and how they can improve
from some of their examples.

So Southwest has had
a great safety record. Only one fatality in
35 years of operation.

They fly only one
make of aircraft. These are Boeing 737's. So as you now know from a
lot of your lean training,

this is going to greatly
simplify all their training procedures, their maintenance,
their logistics on their fleet.

Compare that with an airline
that operates a mixed fleet. They have never had
a layoff of employees

to reduce their costs,
including after the 9/11 downturn in this industry.

They are the most highly
unionized major US airline, which is counter to what
people think intuitively.

I can actually give you some
figures on unionization. As of the writing
of this, we had

Southwest at 84% unionized,
US Air at around 83, United around 81.

And then people
drop off from there. So it's not that it's
a non-union airline.

Southwest Airlines also
has point-to-point service and not hub-and-spoke, in
terms of a route structure.

And the thing to
note about this is that, actually, point-to-point
route structures tend to be
less-profitable business models than hub-and-spoke
business models.

So already, Southwest is a
little bit at a disadvantage, in terms of revenues,
because they're not

generating as many revenues. But yet, they maintain
great profits. They consistently offer
you some of the lowest

fares in this industry. They're a favorite of both
investors and employees alike.

Investors judge by the
stock price of this airline and the capitalization. So what is it, exactly, that
makes Southwest so successful?

Now, Professor
Hoffer Gittell argues in her book, The
Southwest Airlines Way, that it's really a function of
their organizational competency

and their ability
to build and sustain high-performance relationships. And those are characterized by
shared goals, shared knowledge,

and mutual respect.  She introduces a concept
called relational coordination.

And she says there
are three components of relational coordination. One is shared goals. And these align
employees to prioritize

the success of the organization
over their individual success-- over just doing their job.

And the shared
goals for Southwest are safety, satisfied customers,
and on-time departure. It's very simple.

Second aspect of
relational coordination is shared knowledge. This enables visibility
across all the different work

processes. And at Southwest,
the functional groups actually help each other. There's no issues with,
well, this is my job,

and that's your job. And I'm not going to do your
job, because it's not my job. Everybody helps out
and handles everything.

Third element in relational
coordination is mutual respect. And this helps reduce
barriers between people--

employees and
groups of employees. And Southwest treats
each employee group as just important as any other.

And if you understand a
little bit about airlines, you may have heard about the
pilots union and the flight

attendants union and
the mechanics union and the shareholders
and the managers. It's an organization-- it's
an industry that's often

talked about in terms of groups
of employees always arguing for the best interests
of their group.

And Southwest
treats its employees as-- they're all important.

And we have to keep in mind
that relational coordination-- these three elements of
shared goal, shared knowledge,

and mutual respect-- cannot be achieved without
effective communication among all the people participating
in the enterprise.

And Southwest encourages
their employees to do this by communicating
about the problem itself

rather than thinking
about assigning blame. Another way to
think about this is, let's talk about the
problems and not the people.

Separate out the people
from whatever is happening that's giving us some troubles.

And we want to remind
you that this kind of open and honest
communication-- and we heard a flavor of this talked
about at the New Balance

tour in terms of having
meetings try to be productive. Working towards
effective communications

is really a hallmark of
lean-thinking organizations.

So we've talked about
relational coordination. It sounds good, but
does it actually do a lot for my enterprise
in terms of productivity?

And can I see that, or
can I start to prove that? So what Dr. Hoffer
Gittell did was

she surveyed a number
of different airlines and produced this graph to
summarize some of the results.

What you see on the
x-axis is a measure of performance for
an airline, which

is a combination of a lot
of different factors rolled into one. And what you see on
the y-axis, which

has gotten a little bit
messed up in translation here, is a measure of relational
coordination that is achieved.

And each of these dots
represents a different airline and a different facility
in different locations around the country. So there's Southwest and a bunch
of other airlines scattered

in here. And what you see
is that Southwest, which has a pretty high
relational coordination,

is also doing very well on
their performance index.

So we might assume, then, that
the relational coordination,

and improving that, will result
in increased performance. And that was for airlines. But what about other industries?

So she did the same
study for hospitals and saw very much a same
result. So as you increase

on your performance in
relational coordination, you tend to increase in your
productivity performance as well.

So does this actually move
beyond airlines and hospitals?

I don't have data
for you on that. But I'll suggest that this
kind of relational coordination

is a big issue in all kinds
of other work settings where there are certain
characteristics, one of task

interdependence, where there's a
lot of handoffs or codependence between items-- they may involve
feedback and iterations,

like a design cycle-- where there's a
lot of uncertainty, and there may be a lot of
adjusting of plans that have

to happen-- so a lot of
communication is necessary-- or places where there's a
lot of time constraints,

and so buffers for working
out the relational issues just wouldn't exist.

So some of the
example work settings where this might
actually apply-- we think product development. Lots of team
coordination, certainly

lots of feedback and iteration
and lots of uncertainty as you go forward with a design. We saw production in
our LEGO simulation.

Operations will be the same. And you can probably
think of a lot of others. It's probably easier
to think of settings

where this would
apply, being engineers and how much we work in
teams, than in settings where this wouldn't apply.

Yeah, Earll? EARLL MURMAN: For
this group, one of the things this
department does is encourage a lot of
teamwork and study groups

and things like that. That's another workplace
activity [INAUDIBLE]..

ANNALISA WEIGEL: Absolutely. It's a type of
workplace activity where this comes into play.

And it's also partly
the reason why we encourage a lot of
this work in our AeroAstro undergraduate
curriculum, because it's

going to be very important
when you go to take jobs.

So in studying Southwest
a little bit further, Dr. Hoffer Gittell
looked at these outcomes

in terms of the performance, in
terms of quality and efficiency for airlines.

And she looked at
some of the practices that Southwest Airlines
had for achieving that. And she grouped them
into these 10 categories.

And I'm not going to go into
detail on any one of them. But should you be interested,
you can pick up her book

and get some more
information on that. But it's important to
understand that this is not a menu of things that
you're going to choose from.

These are 10 practices
that all must exist to enable effective
relational coordination to gain
your outcome.

So if you have good
relational coordination, what else does that get you? Leads you to higher reliability,
better customer satisfaction,

shorter turnaround time--
all of these things very good for an airline.

And when you have
workforce productivity, you're going to get more revenue
from more satisfied customers

who keep coming back. If you have a smaller
turnaround time, you're going to have airplanes
more in the air and earning

money for you-- value-added time as opposed
to non-value-added time, to put this in a lean context.

You have less employee
turnover if you're a happy, productive workforce. You have reduced cost from not
having your employees idle,

because they're productive. And you, in the end, have
happy, satisfied employees, which are productive employees,
which are happy employees.

So we've established this
link between worker motivation

and attitudes and
enterprise productivity. So how does this all
apply to you here today?

And we're going
to talk about how you can improve the
effectiveness of people

operating in a team environment
and improving their process. And there's two elements that
we're going to talk about.

The first is what goes
on in a leadership role to facilitate teams
being effective.

And we'll talk about
leadership and management. And the second aspect
we're going to talk about is teamwork--

being able to work
effectively and collaborate in groups of people. And you're going to find, over
the course of your career--

and sometimes from day to
day or even hour to hour-- you will be switching between
all of these various roles.

And in one circumstance,
you may be leading a team. At the next meeting, you may
be working as part of the team.

And you may also find yourself
responsible as a manager for a particular project. So these roles are going to
be ones that keep coming up

over the course of your career. And for reasons we're
going to discuss soon, you're actually
going to be taking

on a lot of these
responsibilities earlier than engineers who
were maybe in this industry a couple of decades ago.

So these kind of skills
are very important.

As we said when we started out
here, people are key to lean. If the people don't
want to do it,

lean is not going
to be successful. People are really at the
heart of this enterprise.

The enterprise is
all about people. We have organizational
structures. They exist to enable people.

We have processes which
tell us how people work. And we have tasks,
which is what people do.

So if you had an assembly
plant without people, if you had a business that
did not have people in it,

would they actually be
able to produce something to deliver value
to make a profit?

Absolutely not. And that's why
human resources are talked about as the
most important resource on any project.

Let's talk for a minute
to distinguish leadership from management. Both are very necessary.

And you're probably going to
have to do both of these things over the course of your career. You can summarize
leadership in a catch phrase

as "doing the right thing." And you can contrast
that with management, which is, once you've selected
the right thing to do,

management is understanding
how to do that thing right. So a leader will focus on the
organization and the people

within the organization,
talking about vision and values, and engaging them and empowering
them and making change.

A management focus will
look at goal attainment. So we're talking
decision-making, how we're going to structure
an organization, what we need

for human resources,
how we manage conflicts, and how we get the other
kind of resources-- fiscal, technological--
that we're going to need.

You need both leadership
and management in order to effectively motivate a
team and get them productive

and engaged in their task.  I want to step back in
history a little bit

and talk about how
organizational charts and structures have evolved
in the aerospace industry.

Back from the '60s, we started
with matrix organizations. And I'm sure that
many of you have

heard this terminology before. It's usually represented
in this manner. And we think about functions
going down the vertical here

and programs that
might utilize people from each of those functions
going across the horizontal.

And so a worker would sit
here at the intersection of a program and a function. And they would have two bosses.

They would have their
functional boss-- so maybe they're in structures
or propulsion or thermal.

And then they would have
their program manager, who is a second boss for them.

And this matrix organization
arose because technologies were changing so quickly
that the programs wanted

to be able to draw
on the expertise from all the different
engineering departments. And they thought
that this would allow

them to respond more agiley
to the kind of situation they found for their products.

Now as we change some
of the situations we find ourself in in aerospace,
where it's not necessarily

about the change of
the technology-- we may be refining our processes. We may be driving down costs.

We may be responding
to different needs-- we are moving towards
a different structure. We call it the integrated
product and process teams.

Now, one of the challenges
of this matrix organization-- if you sat here, if you wanted
to talk to somebody here,

you don't have any direct
link through those. So you go to one of your
bosses or to another boss or, gosh forbid,
to both or a third

before you get down to talk to
the person you really need to. So there's a lot of
filtering of information

and ineffective communications. One of the things that the
IPPT has successfully done

is that it now
lets communication happen at the level
where work is being done. It drives down
this communications

to where it's most effective. Now you don't have filters
on all of the talking that's going on and the coordination.

Now, notice, as a result
of this new structure,

people who are in
integrated product teams have to be responsible for a
lot more managing and leading

than they were doing in
a matrix organization, where you sat in
the organization, and you had not just one but
two bosses, or maybe more

if you worked for
several programs. Now, here, you are working
in lower-level teams that are really tackling
different problems.

And you all are providing your
own leadership and management and guidance for that.

So if you are now responsible
for doing a lot more in terms of leading and
managing, it makes sense

that companies are putting more
resources towards developing your skills in that area. Companies are offering training.

They're valuing experiences
like this in school where we're able to develop
some of those characteristics.

And just to give you some
examples from company literature that talk
about this, this

is from Boeing Air Force Systems
Employee Involvement Strategy. They produce whole
documents to try

to help you understand how
to be an effective team player, leader, and manager.

And I'm not going to spend time
talking about these, but more to show you that this is very
important, that people spend

a lot of time
thinking about this and putting together strategies
for helping their employees to do this effectively.

They'll talk about
team behaviors by stages of how teams develop. So teams will start
in a forming stage.

And it takes a while
for them to ramp up to become truly
high-performing teams. And they exhibit different
behaviors and characteristics.

And you can also
talk about leadership in those very same
stages and help you understand how to transition
and grow your leadership

capabilities.  So what I'd like
to do now is engage

in another
active-learning exercise. We call this Personal Values.

rank those values using your grade as a first sort.

All right. So you have five minutes. Go ahead and rank your own
personal values, please.

Those people who actually

Who finished it
